section.title: Updating a Distribution
section.para: Using your distribution definition file, there are two methods to change a system distribution by adding or removing application packages in conjunction with the yum update command option. One method uses the packages element, which addresses the distribution repository only, while the other uses config-rpm, which affects changes within the distribution repository and on the installed client machine.

Regarding updates, if you add a package to your distribution using packages in your samber-server.xml file, yum update will include the package in the distribution repository, which is available for installation. If you add a new package using config-rpm/requires, yum update will include the package in the distribution repository and install it on the client system.

If you choose to update your distribution by removing a package using packages/exclude, yum update will remove the package from the distribution repository but not from the installed client machine. If you use config-rpm/obsoletes, yum update will remove the package from the distribution repository and the installed client system.
Remember that the packages element installs package groups, while the config-rpm element installs packages.

In the example below, you can include two common system administration and network connectivity components: an FTP server and editors. The packages element includes the two common groups, which will be available for installation, while the config-rpm installs associated RPMs on the client machine, as well. Insert the following two lines within the packages element in your samber-server.xml file.
<group>ftp-server</group> <group>editors</group> And within the config-rpm element in your samber-server.xml file, insert these lines to automatically include them on the client machine.
In the next section, you will learn how to add scripts and trigger and activate them based upon key install and uninstall events of other packages.
